newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee heads slightly lower by close.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee heads slightly lower by close.

text.p: LIFFE robusta coffee futures reversed direction to end slightly lower on Friday due to pre-weekend profit taking.

Traders said dealings were slow and they were again dominated by nearby switch trades. July/Sept spread widened again to $20-$25 from $10 on Thursday as players completed the roll-over of the July position into September.
The market was called higher at the open and stayed firm towards the midsession. But it lost ground slightly in the afternoon as New York put up another uninspiring session.
September was traded from a high of $1,895 -- the opening price -- to a low of $1,853, before finishing $4 down at $1,856.
Turnover was a meagre 4,872 lots and the bulk of business was in spread trading. July/Sept traded up to $28 and Sept/Nov at $20.
Technically, analysts expected the market to move in a wide $1,700-$2,000 band basis September in the absence of major market-moving news.
No major cold is in sight in Brazil's coffee areas in the next three to five days.
Private U.S. forecaster Weather Services Corp said temperatures were forecast near normal on Friday and above normal on Saturday and through to Tuesday.
Conditions were generally favourable for the trees but some disruptions to the harvest were still expected from scattered showers.
Elsewhere, Indonesian traders said there had been no news of robusta contract defaults by local firms, who were mostly holding off deals in anticipation of increases in London.
In other news, Peru has declared nine of its 24 regions in emergency on Friday to speed the nation's preparations for the harmful "El Nino" weather system that is expected to form later this year.
The weather phenomemon causes droughts in the south of Peru and heavy rainfalls in the country's north.
